result.markdown:
--- title: "Starting Sampling" draft: true --- ::: callout-note ## Listening ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(broom) library(patchwork) library(here) library(gt) source(here("_defaults.R")) ``` ::: ## Classic Base Rate Issues ```{mermaid} flowchart TD p["population
10,000 individuals"] --> |0.01| v["üßõ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
100 individuals"] p--> |0.99| h["üë®
9,900 individuals"] v --> |0.95| vpos["üßõ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è‚ûï
95 individuals"] v --> |0.05| vneg["üßõ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è‚ûñTest Negative
5 individuals"] h --> |0.01| hpos["üë®‚ûï
99 individuals"] h --> |0.99| hneg["üë®‚ûñTest Negative
9,801 individuals"] vpos --o pos["(üßõ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è,üë®)‚ûï
194"] hpos --o pos vneg --o neg["(üßõ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è, üë®)‚ûñ
9806"] hneg --o neg ``` Plot of the base rate vs P(vampire \| positive test) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tibble( # might as well get logarithmic base_rate = 10^(seq(-3, -1, length = 20)), vamp_and_pos = base_rate * 0.95, vamp_and_neg = base_rate * 0.05, human_and_pos = (1-base_rate) * 0.01, human_and_neg = (1-base_rate) * 0.99, p_vamp_pos = vamp_and_pos/(vamp_and_pos + human_and_pos), p_hum_neg = human_and_neg/(vamp_and_neg + human_and_neg) ) -> test_metrics ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} test_metrics |> ggplot(aes(base_rate, p_vamp_pos))+ geom_point(color = "steelblue", size = 3)+ geom_line(color = "steelblue", linewidth = 1)+ scale_x_log10()+ ylim(0,1)+ labs(x = "P(vampire)", y = "P(vampire | positive)", subtitle = "P(positive | vampire) = 0.95\nP(positive | human) = 0.01", title = "Positive Predictive Value") + theme(plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Probability someone *is* a vampire, given that they tested positive, relative to the base rate of being a vampire](index_files/figure-pdf/fig-ppv-1.png){#fig-ppv fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} test_metrics |> ggplot(aes(base_rate, p_hum_neg))+ geom_point(color = "steelblue", size = 3)+ geom_line(color = "steelblue", linewidth = 1)+ scale_x_log10()+ labs(x = "P(vampire)", y = "P(human | negative)", subtitle = "P(positive | vampire) = 0.95\nP(positive | human) = 0.01", title = "Negative Predictive Value") + theme(plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Probability of being a human given a negative test, relative to the base rate of being a vampire.](index_files/figure-pdf/fig-npv-1.png){#fig-npv fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ## Tibble grid sampling Estimating posterior density from grid sampling. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} grid <- tibble( # The grid prob = seq(0.0001, 0.9999, length = 5000), # the prior prior_unstd = exp(-abs(prob - .5) / .25), prior_std = prior_unstd/sum(prior_unstd), # the data data = dbinom(6, size = 9, prob = prob), # the posterior posterior_unstd = prior_std * data, posterior = posterior_unstd / sum(posterior_unstd) ) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} grid |> ggplot(aes(prob, prior_std))+ geom_line()+ labs(y = "prior density", title = "Prior") -> prior_plot grid |> ggplot(aes(prob, data))+ geom_line()+ labs(y = "data density", title = "Data") -> data_plot grid |> ggplot(aes(prob, posterior))+ geom_line() + labs(y = "posterior density", title = "Posterior") -> posterior_plot prior_plot | data_plot | posterior_plot ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Prior, Data, Posterior](index_files/figure-pdf/fig-posterior1-1.png){#fig-posterior1 fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: Sampling from the posterior, using `sample_n()`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} grid |> sample_n(size = 1e4, replace = T, weight = posterior)-> posterior_samples ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} head(posterior_samples) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 x 6 prob prior_unstd prior_std data posterior_unstd posterior 1 0.876 0.223 0.000103 0.0730 0.00000752 0.0000577 2 0.759 0.354 0.000164 0.224 0.0000368 0.000283 3 0.518 0.932 0.000431 0.181 0.0000782 0.000600 4 0.732 0.395 0.000183 0.249 0.0000455 0.000349 5 0.587 0.705 0.000326 0.242 0.0000790 0.000607 6 0.434 0.768 0.000355 0.102 0.0000361 0.000277 ``` ::: ::: I'm going to mess around with finessing the visualizations here. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} renv::install("tidybayes") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidybayes) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} posterior_samples |> pull(prob) |> density() |> tidy() |> rename(prob = x, density = y) -> posterior_dens posterior_dens |> ggplot(aes(prob, density/max(density)))+ geom_area(fill = "grey60")+ geom_line(aes(y = posterior/max(posterior)), linetype = 2, data = grid)+ theme( axis.title.y = element_blank(), axis.text.y = element_blank(), panel.grid.major.y = element_blank() ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Comparison of the kernel density estimate vs the actual posterior distribution.](index_files/figure-pdf/fig-dens-grid-1.png){#fig-dens-grid fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} posterior_samples |> median_hdci(prob, .width = c(0.5, 0.95)) -> intervals intervals |> gt() |> fmt_number(decimals = 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{longtable}{rrrrll} \toprule prob & .lower & .upper & .width & .point & .interval \\ \midrule $0.59$ & $0.49$ & $0.66$ & $0.50$ & median & hdci \\ $0.59$ & $0.37$ & $0.84$ & $0.95$ & median & hdci \\ \bottomrule \end{longtable} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} posterior_samples |> ggplot(aes(prob))+ stat_slab(aes(fill = after_stat(pdf)), fill_type = "gradient")+ scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0,0)))+ khroma::scale_fill_batlow() + theme( axis.title.y = element_blank(), axis.text.y = element_blank(), panel.grid.major.y = element_blank() ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Posterior density, colored according to the probability density function.](index_files/figure-pdf/fig-pdf-1.png){#fig-pdf fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} posterior_samples |> ggplot(aes(prob))+ stat_slab( aes(fill = after_stat(x >= 0.5)), fill_type = "gradient" ) + scale_fill_manual( values = c( "grey70", "steelblue" ) )+ scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0,0)))+ theme( axis.title.y = element_blank(), axis.text.y = element_blank(), panel.grid.major.y = element_blank() ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![The posterior density colored according to a critical value (0.5)](index_files/figure-pdf/fig-cutoff-1.png){#fig-cutoff fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} posterior_samples |> ggplot(aes(prob))+ stat_halfeye( aes(fill = after_stat(level)), fill_type = "gradient", point_interval = "median_hdi" ) + scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0.05,0)))+ scale_fill_manual( values = c("steelblue", "steelblue4") )+ theme( axis.title.y = element_blank(), axis.text.y = element_blank(), panel.grid.major.y = element_blank() ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Posterior samples, colored by their highest density interval levels.](index_files/figure-pdf/fig-hdi-1.png){#fig-hdi fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: Can I get the plot into a `{gt}` table? I thin I'll need to map over the widths? I'm going off of this gt help page: https://gt.rstudio.com/reference/ggplot_image.html. Let me get the plot right first. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} posterior_samples |> ggplot(aes(prob))+ stat_slab( aes(fill = after_stat(level)), .width = 0.66, fill_type = "gradient", point_interval = "median_hdci" ) + stat_slab( fill = NA, color = "black" )+ scale_x_continuous( limits = c(0,1), expand = expansion(mult = c(0,0)) )+ scale_y_continuous( expand = expansion(mult = c(0,0)) )+ scale_fill_manual(values = "steelblue", guide = "none")+ theme_void() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Table figure experimentation](index_files/figure-pdf/fig-slab-exp-1.png){#fig-slab-exp fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} make_table_plot <- function(.width, data) { ggplot(data, aes(prob))+ stat_slab( aes(fill = after_stat(level)), .width = .width, point_interval = "median_hdci" ) + stat_slab( fill = NA, color = "black" )+ scale_x_continuous( limits = c(0,1), expand = expansion(mult = c(0,0)) )+ scale_y_continuous( expand = expansion(mult = c(0,0)) )+ scale_fill_manual(values = "steelblue", guide = "none")+ theme_void() } ``` ::: Map that function over the `intervals` table I made before. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} intervals |> mutate( ggplot = map(.width, ~make_table_plot(.x, posterior_samples)), ## adding an empty column dist = NA ) -> to_tibble to_tibble |> select(-ggplot) |> gt() |> text_transform( locations = cells_body(columns = dist), fn = \(x) map(to_tibble$ggplot, ggplot_image, aspect_ratio = 2) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{longtable}{rrrrllc} \toprule prob & .lower & .upper & .width & .point & .interval & dist \\ \midrule 0.5927 & 0.4899000 & 0.6593000 & 0.50 & median & hdci & \\ 0.5927 & 0.3725879 & 0.8413879 & 0.95 & median & hdci & \\ \bottomrule \end{longtable} ::: ::: I'd like more control over how the image appears in the table. Looks like I'll have to ggsave, and then embed. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} make_custom_table_plot <- function(p){ filename <- tempfile(fileext = ".png") ggsave(plot = p, filename = filename, device = ragg::agg_png, res = 100, width =1.5, height = 0.75) local_image(filename=filename) } ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} to_tibble |> select(-ggplot) |> gt() |> text_transform( locations = cells_body(columns = vars(dist)), fn = \(x) map(to_tibble$ggplot, make_custom_table_plot) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} \begin{longtable}{rrrrllc} \toprule prob & .lower & .upper & .width & .point & .interval & dist \\ \midrule 0.5927 & 0.4899000 & 0.6593000 & 0.50 & median & hdci & \\ 0.5927 & 0.3725879 & 0.8413879 & 0.95 & median & hdci & \\ \bottomrule \end{longtable} ::: ::: There we go! ## BRMS ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(brms) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tibble( water = 6, samples = 9 )-> water_to_model ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} water_form <- bf( water | trials(samples) ~ 1, family = binomial(link = "identity") ) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} brm( water | trials(samples) ~ 1, data = water_to_model, family = binomial(link = "identity"), prior(beta(1, 1), class = Intercept, ub = 1, lb = 0), file_refit = "on_change", file = "water_fit.rds" ) -> water_model ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} water_model ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Family: binomial Links: mu = identity Formula: water | trials(samples) ~ 1 Data: water_to_model (Number of observations: 1) Draws: 4 chains, each with iter = 2000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1; total post-warmup draws = 4000 Population-Level Effects: Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS Intercept 0.64 0.14 0.35 0.88 1.00 1598 1945 Draws were sampled using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Bulk_ESS and Tail_ESS are effective sample size measures, and Rhat is the potential scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1). ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(gtsummary) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} water_model |> gtsummary::tbl_regression(intercept = T) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} |**Characteristic** | **Beta** | **95% CI** | |:------------------|:--------:|:----------:| |(Intercept) | 0.64 | 0.35, 0.88 | ::: :::
